All .Net bridge related tests failed. Looks like it cannot find  CLR Driver bridge configuration file.

Are we set on the name `Interop`? In all other cases, we call it `Bridge`. Hence, this code could move to `Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.Driver` or such.

@jwang98052 @beysims what do you think?

Currently Og.Apache.REEF.Bridge contains cpp code. 
Are you talking IInteropReturnInfo.cs and ILogger.cs? We can move them into Org.Apache.REEF.Driver.Bridge I think. They were at cpp folder previously. As they are cs files, so put them in to Org.Apache.REEF.Driver.Bridge with other bridge cs code would make more sense.
review comments addressed and pushed.

These basic types do not inherit ISerializable as the base class

You wouldn't have to create a subclass, but instead create a wrapper object. This is done all over the place in Hadoop. The downside is that yes, those wrappers take memory. The centralized serializer we also discussed would avoid that memory overhead.

Would like to see unit test cases.

To verify it, please run all tests in VS to make sure no regression caused by the test refactor. 
The new Yarn test cases are marked as [Ignore] for now. They will be run in Yarn env.

@markusweimer @jwang98052 @beysims 

Please find the modified design.

Files to look at are:

SerializableNsMessage
SerializableGroupCommunicationMessage
and StreamingCodec folder.

This time I have gone with IWritable interface similar to the Hadoop's Writable.
It is assumed that whichever class uses this interface it will have an empty constructor. Moreover, Read function can have optional parameters that are needed to Decode NsMessage. The messages will and are being instantiated using Reflection.

This pull request looks good
I'll test this.
I'll test this.
@dkm2110 Arent'd arrays types, too? As in `typof(double[])` should evaluate to the type needed in `SerializationInfo`, right?

@markusweimer @beysims @jwang98052 

my main worry is that in this case we are relying on some internal serialization mechanism to encode arrays. Is it supposed to be optimal or we are better off writing our own IWritable.
I don't know. @beysims ?

@markusweimer @beysims @jwang98052 

Hey, so irrespective of the issue that whether we have IWritable or Serializable since changing one from another is not a huge effort/issue, I am making lots of changes in both Wake as well as Network Layer. The main changes are related to removing Codecs from the constructors and the final Link.cs writes to stream directly. This means that all the tests based earlier on these codecs fail and are giving errors. Now I have two ways: a) I rewrite the tests converting everything to IWritable in the tests b) I retain the codec constructors in the classes but inside the constructor I wrap it and convert to IWritable. This way the tests will be retained.

Any suggestions which way is better than the other? I guess question is more on coding ethics side.

Dhruv
